awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Printable electron transport layers (PrETLs) for organic electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is the development of printable electron transport layer (PrETL) materials to greatly simplify the production of organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs) and significantly lower their manufacturing cost.  OLEDs are found in an increasingly broad range of commercial products, such as televisions, portable devices, automotive lighting, flexible luminaries, and displays.  Current commercial OLED manufacturing technologies typically require methods that are expensive, energy intensive, and slow. The biggest barrier preventing the transition from thermal evaporation to printable technologies has been a lack of commercially available printable electron transport layers. The adoption of PrETL technology will allow manufacturers to eliminate the thermal evaporation steps and enable fully-printed OLEDs at a fraction of the cost of current devices.  This development will spur further penetration of OLEDs throughout the lighting and display market, providing the benefits of improved energy-efficiency, reduced eye-strain, flexible forms, minimal heat production, and lower cost device.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses the lack of efficient, long-lifetime, printable electron transport layers (PrETLs) for organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs). The objectives of this project are to demonstrate the feasibility of PrETLs and PrETL-enabled, fully printed OLEDs.  The innovative PrETLs developed here rely on a solution processable hexacoordinate silicon-based scaffold, that can be synthetically tuned to the electronic and material needs of the manufacturer. The Phase I project will develop PrETL thin films for material and electronic testing and for building prototype OLEDs enabled by PrETLs.  The ultimate anticipated outcome of the proposed Phase I research will be a fully printed PrETL-enabled OLED with an external quantum efficiency greater than 10% and a lifetime of 10,000 hours at 1,000 nit brightness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Light and Charge Solutions, LLC in partnership with researchers from the University of North Carolina at Charlotte and Argonne National Laboraties executed a Phase 1 STTR to explore the feasibility of Si(pincer)2 complexes as Printable Electron Transport Layers (PrETLs) in fully-printed organic light emitting diodes, OLEDs. Fully-printed OLEDs have the potential to significantly lower the cost, reduce the environmental impact, and add new shape and functional flexibility to the OLED lighting and display market. A primary barrier to fully printed organic electronic devices, however, is the lack of printable electron transport layer materials.  

Intellectual merit:  The feasibility of Si(pincer)­2 complexes as PrETLs was explored. Si(pincer)2 complexes are a hexacoordinate silicon complex with an innovative molecular design, comprised of a central electron withdrawing silicon center surrounded by two conjugated, dianionic pincer ligands. The Si(pincer)2 motif provides increases stability and charge mobility with orbital energies suited for electron transport and hole blocking. During the course of the STTR, several new Si(pincer)2 complexes were synthesized and analyzed, and six targets were identified as having electronic levels appropriate for commercial devices. Three targets were identified as having electron mobility levels comparable to commercial ETLs.  Synthetic modification of the complexes led to increased solubility necessary for solution-processability. Films of Si(pincer)2 PrETLs have been solution-cast and are currently being analyzed prior to integration into prototype devices.

Broader Impacts: Low-cost, high-performance printable electron transport layer materials are critically needed for transformation of the OLED manufacturing industry away from thermal evaporation process to low-cost printing processes. This will bring about significant cost reductions in OLED fabrication, which can be passed on to the end-user. Achieving fully-printable OLEDs through the development of PrETLs will increase OLED market penetration resulting in positive societal impacts through reduced energy usage, positive health outcomes, lower prices for existing products, and innovative products providing human benefits. In addition to the societal benefit of the technology, this STTR also contributed to the education and training of 2 graduate students.


Last Modified: 05/01/2023
Modified by: Margaret Kocherga
